Description: Limestone ostracon: on the recto six lines of text containing measurements of elements of a royal tomb. On the verso two lines of text continuing the text on the recto and at right angles to two standing figures of Osiris Wennefer.
Curator's comments: According to C. Rossi in ‘Göttinger Miszellen’ 187 (Göttingen, 2002), id. 'Journal of Egyptian Archaeology' 87 (2001), the architectural elements recorded suggest that the tomb described is that of Queen Isis, QV 51, built under Ramses VI. This dating also corresponds to the palaeography of the text. Bibliography: S. Birch, 'Inscriptions in the Hieratic and Demotic Character, from the Collections of the British Museum' (London 1868), pl. VI; J. J. Černy and A.H. Gardiner, ‘Hieratic Ostraca’ (Oxford 1957), pp. 23-4 and pl. LXXXVII, 3; J. J. Černy, 'The Valley of the Kings' (Cairo 1973), pp. 25—6; R.J. Demaree, 'Royal Riddles', in R.J. Demaree and A. Egberts (eds), 'Village Voices' (Leiden, 1992), p. 13.
Bibliographic references: Trismegistos / An interdisciplinary portal of papyrological and epigraphic resources (136364) (http://www.trismegistos.org/text/136364)
Associated places: Named in inscription: Biban el-Muluk (Valley of the Kings - Thebes), tomb
Acquisition name: Purchased from: Somerset Lowry-Corry, 2nd Earl of Belmore
